channel.title: Global News Podcast
channel.description: The dayâ€™s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:summary: The dayâ€™s top stories from BBC News. Delivered twice a day on weekdays, daily at weekends
channel.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN vows to address human rights concerns in China
item.description: The new human rights commissioner Volker TÃ¼rk was speaking at a press conference to mark human rights day. Also: A Russian politician has been convicted of spreading false information about the war in Ukraine and the Japanese billionaire taking celebrities with him to the moon...
item.itunes:subtitle: A recent UN report said Beijingâ€™s treatment of Uyghurs could be a crime against humanity
item.itunes:summary: The new human rights commissioner Volker TÃ¼rk was speaking at a press conference to mark human rights day. Also: A Russian politician has been convicted of spreading false information about the war in Ukraine and the Japanese billionaire taking celebrities with him to the moon...
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US bill protecting same-sex marriage clears Congress
item.description: The legislation will enshrine marriage equality in federal law, protecting the rights of same-sex and interracial couples. Also: the chief executive of the Qatar World Cup is criticised for comments about the death of a migrant worker, and Celine Dion is diagnosed with a rare neurological disease.
item.itunes:subtitle: The legislation will enshrine marriage equality in federal law
item.itunes:summary: The legislation will enshrine marriage equality in federal law, protecting the rights of same-sex and interracial couples. Also: the chief executive of the Qatar World Cup is criticised for comments about the death of a migrant worker, and Celine Dion is diagnosed with a rare neurological disease.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US basketball star exchanged for Russian arms dealer
item.description: President Biden welcomes a prisoner swap with Russia involving US basketball star, Brittney Griner, and the arms dealer, Viktor Bout. Also: Iran executes its first demonstrator since the start of protests, and M23 rebels in DR Congo deny they're supported by Rwanda.
item.itunes:subtitle: Joe Biden says Brittney Griner is in good spirits and relieved to be heading home
item.itunes:summary: President Biden welcomes a prisoner swap with Russia involving US basketball star, Brittney Griner, and the arms dealer, Viktor Bout. Also: Iran executes its first demonstrator since the start of protests, and M23 rebels in DR Congo deny they're supported by Rwanda.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Peru has new president after dramatic impeachment
item.description: Ex-president Pedro Castillo was impeached after he tried to dissolve Congress. Also: the Taliban carry out the first public execution since their return to power in Afghanistan, and ancient DNA reveals what the Arctic looked like two million years ago.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dina Boluarte - previously the vice-president - has been sworn in as head of state
item.itunes:summary: Ex-president Pedro Castillo was impeached after he tried to dissolve Congress. Also: the Taliban carry out the first public execution since their return to power in Afghanistan, and ancient DNA reveals what the Arctic looked like two million years ago.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China abandons key elements of zero-Covid policy
item.description: It follows rare anti-government protests last week across the country. Also: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Saudi Arabia to strengthen China-Arab relations, and 25 people are arrested in Germany on suspicion of plotting to overthrow the government.
item.itunes:subtitle: It follows rare anti-government protests last week across the country
item.itunes:summary: It follows rare anti-government protests last week across the country. Also: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Saudi Arabia to strengthen China-Arab relations, and 25 people are arrested in Germany on suspicion of plotting to overthrow the government.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump Organization is found guilty of tax crimes
item.description: The business is synonymous with the former US president Donald Trump but neither he or his family were on trial. Also: Argentina's Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner is found guilty of corruption, and the loneliness of a book signing event.
item.itunes:subtitle: Untaxed perks included luxury cars and private school fees
item.itunes:summary: The business is synonymous with the former US president Donald Trump but neither he or his family were on trial. Also: Argentina's Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner is found guilty of corruption, and the loneliness of a book signing event.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Indonesia outlaws sex outside marriage
item.description: New law also introduces tougher punishment for blasphemy. Also: China bids farewell to its former leader Jiang Zemin, and the actress Kirsty Alley has died at the age of 71.
item.itunes:subtitle: New law also introduces tougher punishment for blasphemy
item.itunes:summary: New law also introduces tougher punishment for blasphemy. Also: China bids farewell to its former leader Jiang Zemin, and the actress Kirsty Alley has died at the age of 71.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia blames Ukraine for attacks on two airfields
item.description: A number of people were killed at the Russian airfields, which Moscow blames on Ukrainian drones. Also: ANC backs South African president over corruption report, and the pioneering tennis coach Nick Bollettieri dies aged 91.
item.itunes:subtitle: In response, Russia fired a barrage of missiles across Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: A number of people were killed at the Russian airfields, which Moscow blames on Ukrainian drones. Also: ANC backs South African president over corruption report, and the pioneering tennis coach Nick Bollettieri dies aged 91.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trial begins for 2016 Brussels terror attacks
item.description: Ten men are accused of involvement in the bombings, which killed 32 people. Also: human rights groups in Haiti tell the BBC that gangs control at least 60 percent of the capital city, and the missing remains of the last Tasmanian tiger are discovered.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ten men are accused of involvement in bombings which killed 32 people
item.itunes:summary: Ten men are accused of involvement in the bombings, which killed 32 people. Also: human rights groups in Haiti tell the BBC that gangs control at least 60 percent of the capital city, and the missing remains of the last Tasmanian tiger are discovered.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Protestors storm government office in southern Syria
item.description: There have been a number of deaths during rare demonstrations in the southern Syrian city of Sweida. Also: the Tigrayan force chief in northern Ethiopia says many of his fighters have pulled back from the battle front, and a happy 190th birthday to Jonathan the giant tortoise.
item.itunes:subtitle: The crowds were angry because of the worsening economic conditions in Syria
item.itunes:summary: There have been a number of deaths during rare demonstrations in the southern Syrian city of Sweida. Also: the Tigrayan force chief in northern Ethiopia says many of his fighters have pulled back from the battle front, and a happy 190th birthday to Jonathan the giant tortoise.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russian oil cap 'weak' says Zelensky
item.description: The Ukrainian President added that it would not stop Russia's war in his country. Also: A spokesman for the South African President Cyril Ramaphosa has said he won't resign despite a scandal over money stolen from his farm, and the discovery on a bookshelf in the US of one of Stephen Sondheim's earliest musicals.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ukrainian President added that it would not stop Russia's war in his country
item.itunes:summary: The Ukrainian President added that it would not stop Russia's war in his country. Also: A spokesman for the South African President Cyril Ramaphosa has said he won't resign despite a scandal over money stolen from his farm, and the discovery on a bookshelf in the US of one of Stephen Sondheim's earliest musicals.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: EU imposes Russian oil price cap
item.description: The aim is to starve Moscow of funds for its war against Ukraine. Also: The World Health Organisation says it's struggling to reach people in need of help in the Ethiopian region of Tigray, weeks after a ceasefire was agreed, and why a Barbadian task force is asking a British MP for slavery reparations.
item.itunes:subtitle: The aim is to starve Moscow of funds for its war against Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: The aim is to starve Moscow of funds for its war against Ukraine. Also: The World Health Organisation says it's struggling to reach people in need of help in the Ethiopian region of Tigray, weeks after a ceasefire was agreed, and why a Barbadian task force is asking a British MP for slavery reparations.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: 'Evil' Russian invasion must fail, says Anglican church head
item.description: Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, was speaking after visiting recently liberated towns in Ukraine. Also: Kanye West is suspended from Twitter again, News from Elsewhere and the transatlantic centenarian penpals.
item.itunes:subtitle: Justin Welby was speaking after visiting recently liberated towns in Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: Archbishop of Canterbury, Justin Welby, was speaking after visiting recently liberated towns in Ukraine. Also: Kanye West is suspended from Twitter again, News from Elsewhere and the transatlantic centenarian penpals.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Biden prepared to speak to Putin
item.description: But only if the Russian President showed a desire to end the war in Ukraine. Also: Further violence in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo has pushed a ceasefire close to collapse, and Harissa is given cultural heritage status by the UN.
item.itunes:subtitle: But only if the Russian President showed a desire to end the war in Ukraine.
item.itunes:summary: But only if the Russian President showed a desire to end the war in Ukraine. Also: Further violence in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo has pushed a ceasefire close to collapse, and Harissa is given cultural heritage status by the UN.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China eases Covid restrictions in some cities
item.description: It comes after mass protests against its zero-Covid policy. Also: In Afghanistan the Taliban orders Voice of America to stop broadcasting, Spain steps up security after a spate of letter bombs, and New York ties with Singapore to be the most expensive on Earth.
item.itunes:subtitle: It comes after mass protests against its zero-Covid policy
item.itunes:summary: It comes after mass protests against its zero-Covid policy. Also: In Afghanistan the Taliban orders Voice of America to stop broadcasting, Spain steps up security after a spate of letter bombs, and New York ties with Singapore to be the most expensive on Earth.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ramaphosa faces threat of impeachment
item.description: Report finds the South African President may have breached anti-corruption law. Also: The Islamic State group has announced the death of its leader, Abu al-Hassan al-Quraishi, and Christine McVie -- who was behind some of Fleetwood Mac's biggest hits -- has died.
item.itunes:subtitle: Report finds the South African President may have breached anti-corruption law
item.itunes:summary: Report finds the South African President may have breached anti-corruption law. Also: The Islamic State group has announced the death of its leader, Abu al-Hassan al-Quraishi, and Christine McVie -- who was behind some of Fleetwood Mac's biggest hits -- has died.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Alzheimer's drug hailed as momentous breakthrough
item.description: Lecanemab slows damage to the brain in the early stages of the disease. Also: Jiang Zemin, who led China after the Tiananmen Square massacre, has died aged 96, and how bats can outsing humans.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lecanemab slows damage to the brain in the early stages of the disease
item.itunes:summary: Lecanemab slows damage to the brain in the early stages of the disease. Also: Jiang Zemin, who led China after the Tiananmen Square massacre, has died aged 96, and how bats can outsing humans.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Nato promises Ukraine more weapons and power grid support
item.description: Millions of Ukrainians remain without power in freezing temperatures after Russian strikes. Also: jailed Belarus protest leader Maria Kolesnikova is "in intensive care", and China sends astronauts to live on its space station.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia is accused of "trying to use winter as a weapon of war"
item.itunes:summary: Millions of Ukrainians remain without power in freezing temperatures after Russian strikes. Also: jailed Belarus protest leader Maria Kolesnikova is "in intensive care", and China sends astronauts to live on its space station.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Nato discusses support amid power outages
item.description: Foreign ministers discuss how best to support Ukraine, as a fresh wave of attacks cut off water and power supplies. Also: China responds to lockdown protests, and a Balenciaga advertising campaign sparks major backlash.
item.itunes:subtitle: Foreign ministers discuss how best to support Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: Foreign ministers discuss how best to support Ukraine, as a fresh wave of attacks cut off water and power supplies. Also: China responds to lockdown protests, and a Balenciaga advertising campaign sparks major backlash.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Somali hotel siege ends after lengthy battle
item.description: A number of civilians died after al-Shabab militants stormed a hotel near the presidential palace in Mogadishu. Also: demonstrations in China over Covid restrictions appear to have died down, and Nigeria praises UK museum for returning Benin Bronzes.
item.itunes:subtitle: Witnesses heard large explosions at the Villa Rays hotel
item.itunes:summary: A number of civilians died after al-Shabab militants stormed a hotel near the presidential palace in Mogadishu. Also: demonstrations in China over Covid restrictions appear to have died down, and Nigeria praises UK museum for returning Benin Bronzes.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Europol dismantles massive drugs 'super cartel'
item.description: Police say it controlled around a third of Europe's cocaine trade. Also: China seeks to end widespread protests against coronavirus restrictions, and why Bob Dylan is having to apologise to his fans.
item.itunes:subtitle: Police say it controlled around a third of Europe's cocaine trade
item.itunes:summary: Police say it controlled around a third of Europe's cocaine trade. Also: China seeks to end widespread protests against coronavirus restrictions, and why Bob Dylan is having to apologise to his fans.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: China Covid protests spread to major cities
item.description: In defiant scenes not usually seen in China, demonstrators have called for President Xi Jinping to stand down. Also: Italy declares a state of emergency on the island of Ischia following a deadly landslide, and a Frenchman who was sacked for refusing to join work parties wins the legal right to be boring.
item.itunes:subtitle: Demonstrators have called for President Xi Jinping to stand down
item.itunes:summary: In defiant scenes not usually seen in China, demonstrators have called for President Xi Jinping to stand down. Also: Italy declares a state of emergency on the island of Ischia following a deadly landslide, and a Frenchman who was sacked for refusing to join work parties wins the legal right to be boring.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Pakistan: Imran Khan hosts huge protest rally
item.description: The former prime minister greeted hundreds of thousands of supporters in Rawalpindi, weeks after he was shot at a similar event. Also: the US has banned the sale of Chinese technology amid security fears, and 100 years after Tutankhamun's tomb was uncovered, we examine the role that Egyptian archaeologists played in the discovery.
item.itunes:subtitle: The former PM greeted supporters in Rawalpindi weeks after he was shot at a similar event
item.itunes:summary: The former prime minister greeted hundreds of thousands of supporters in Rawalpindi, weeks after he was shot at a similar event. Also: the US has banned the sale of Chinese technology amid security fears, and 100 years after Tutankhamun's tomb was uncovered, we examine the role that Egyptian archaeologists played in the discovery.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN urges Russia and Ukraine to protect POWs
item.description: Human rights officials raise concerns as evidence emerges of possible summary executions by both sides. Also: Iranian activists say the security forces have opened fire on protesters in the eastern province of Sistan-Balochistan, and a musical based on the life of Nelson Mandela is set to open in London.
item.itunes:subtitle: Evidence has emerged of possible summary executions by both sides
item.itunes:summary: Human rights officials raise concerns as evidence emerges of possible summary executions by both sides. Also: Iranian activists say the security forces have opened fire on protesters in the eastern province of Sistan-Balochistan, and a musical based on the life of Nelson Mandela is set to open in London.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine: Millions face winter without power
item.description: First lady Zelenska says Ukraine will endure cold and blackouts caused by Russian bombs. Also: scientists say they have made a breakthrough designing a vaccine against all 20 known types of flu, and is it time to end gender specific categories in film and TV awards?
item.itunes:subtitle: First lady Zelenska says Ukraine will endure cold and blackouts caused by Russian bombs
item.itunes:summary: First lady Zelenska says Ukraine will endure cold and blackouts caused by Russian bombs. Also: scientists say they have made a breakthrough designing a vaccine against all 20 known types of flu, and is it time to end gender specific categories in film and TV awards?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: UN orders investigation into Iran crackdown
item.description: Western diplomats say the mission will send a powerful signal of support to Iranian women. Also: Half of Ukraine's electricity needs are now being met, following repairs to infrastructure damaged by Russian missiles, and we meet the world's longest survivor of heart transplant surgery.
item.itunes:subtitle: Western diplomats say it will send a powerful signal of support to Iranian women.
item.itunes:summary: Western diplomats say the mission will send a powerful signal of support to Iranian women. Also: Half of Ukraine's electricity needs are now being met, following repairs to infrastructure damaged by Russian missiles, and we meet the world's longest survivor of heart transplant surgery.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Afghans forced to sell organs and sedate hungry children
item.description: In the second winter since the Taliban takeover, UN says millions are at risk of famine. Also: China reports highest number of daily coronavirus infections, despite continuing restrictions; and more than 140 people arrested in international police operation targeting scammers.
item.itunes:subtitle: In the second winter since the Taliban takeover, UN says millions are at risk of famine
item.itunes:summary: In the second winter since the Taliban takeover, UN says millions are at risk of famine. Also: China reports highest number of daily coronavirus infections, despite continuing restrictions; and more than 140 people arrested in international police operation targeting scammers.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Zelensky accuses Russia of crimes against humanity
item.description: The Ukrainian leader tells the UN Russia offers nothing to the world apart from terror. Also: African leaders declare a cessation of hostilities in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and the discovery of the world's oldest bread.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Ukrainian leader tells the UN Russia offers nothing to the world apart from terror
item.itunes:summary: The Ukrainian leader tells the UN Russia offers nothing to the world apart from terror. Also: African leaders declare a cessation of hostilities in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, and the discovery of the world's oldest bread.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia launches another wave of missile strikes across Ukraine
item.description: Key infrastructure hit, hours after a 2-day old baby was killed in a Zaporizhzhya hospital where his mother survived. We hear about the extent of the damage. Also: In Jerusalem, a teenage boy dies after bus stop bombings - the first such attacks for several years, and we look back at the life of the Dr Feelgood guitarist, Wilko Johnson, who's died aged 75.
item.itunes:subtitle: Key infrastructure hit, hours after a newborn baby was killed in a Zaporizhzhya hospital
item.itunes:summary: Key infrastructure hit, hours after a 2-day old baby was killed in a Zaporizhzhya hospital where his mother survived. We hear about the extent of the damage. Also: In Jerusalem, a teenage boy dies after bus stop bombings - the first such attacks for several years, and we look back at the life of the Dr Feelgood guitarist, Wilko Johnson, who's died aged 75.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Trump loses bid to withhold tax returns
item.description: The US Supreme Court has approved their release to a Congressional committee, marking a legal defeat for the former Republican President. Also, a national holiday is declared in Saudi Arabia to celebrate a shock win against Argentina in the World Cup, and the Ugandan man appealing for help with the upkeep of his 10 wives and 102 children.
item.itunes:subtitle: The US Supreme Court has approved their release to a Congressional committee
item.itunes:summary: The US Supreme Court has approved their release to a Congressional committee, marking a legal defeat for the former Republican President. Also, a national holiday is declared in Saudi Arabia to celebrate a shock win against Argentina in the World Cup, and the Ugandan man appealing for help with the upkeep of his 10 wives and 102 children.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Rescuers in Indonesia battle to find earthquake survivors
item.description: Disaster agency says number killed in West Java reaches two-hundred and sixty-eight. Also: Ukraine's security services conduct searches at the country's most famous monastery to check if it's being used for subversive activities to help Russia, and Saudi Arabia have beaten one of the favourites, Argentina in the football World Cup - the first big shock of the competition.
item.itunes:subtitle: Disaster agency says number killed in West Java reaches two-hundred and sixty-eight
item.itunes:summary: Disaster agency says number killed in West Java reaches two-hundred and sixty-eight. Also: Ukraine's security services conduct searches at the country's most famous monastery to check if it's being used for subversive activities to help Russia, and Saudi Arabia have beaten one of the favourites, Argentina in the football World Cup - the first big shock of the competition.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Iran football players decline to sing national anthem in Qatar
item.description: The Iranian national team stayed silent in the World Cup stadium in Doha as their anthem was played. Also: WHO says millions of Ukrainian lives are under threat as winter sets in, and Nasa's Artemis spacecraft arrives at an orbit around the Moon.
item.itunes:subtitle: It was an expression of support for anti-government protests in Iran
item.itunes:summary: The Iranian national team stayed silent in the World Cup stadium in Doha as their anthem was played. Also: WHO says millions of Ukrainian lives are under threat as winter sets in, and Nasa's Artemis spacecraft arrives at an orbit around the Moon.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Indonesia earthquake kills more than 60
item.description: The 5.6 magnitude quake struck Cianjur town in West Java and was felt a hundred kilometres away in the capital, Jakarta. Also: several European teams at the World Cup in Qatar scrap plans to wear armbands in support of gay rights; and China confirms three people have died in Beijing with Covid - the first fatalities officially connected to the disease in six months.
item.itunes:subtitle: The 5.6 magnitude quake struck Cianjur town in West Java
item.itunes:summary: The 5.6 magnitude quake struck Cianjur town in West Java and was felt a hundred kilometres away in the capital, Jakarta. Also: several European teams at the World Cup in Qatar scrap plans to wear armbands in support of gay rights; and China confirms three people have died in Beijing with Covid - the first fatalities officially connected to the disease in six months.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Hosts Qatar beaten by Ecuador in World Cup opener
item.description: The football tournament began in Qatar with a lavish opening ceremony at Al-Bayt stadium near Doha. Also: leading Argentinian campaigner Hebe de Bonafini dies aged 93, and the British artist David Hockney joins immersive art trend with new London show.
item.itunes:subtitle: The Fifa World Cup tournament ends on the 18th of December
item.itunes:summary: The football tournament began in Qatar with a lavish opening ceremony at Al-Bayt stadium near Doha. Also: leading Argentinian campaigner Hebe de Bonafini dies aged 93, and the British artist David Hockney joins immersive art trend with new London show.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Fifa World Cup begins in Qatar
item.description: After 12 years of questions and criticisms, the 2022 Fifa World Cup finally gets underway in Qatar. Also: UN climate talks continue into the night to reach a deal, and who invented the electric toaster?
item.itunes:subtitle: It's the first tournament to be held in a Muslim country
item.itunes:summary: After 12 years of questions and criticisms, the 2022 Fifa World Cup finally gets underway in Qatar. Also: UN climate talks continue into the night to reach a deal, and who invented the electric toaster?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: US special counsel to oversee criminal investigation into Trump
item.description: A former war crimes prosecutor, Jack Smith, was named special counsel by US Attorney General, Merrrick Garland. Also: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes jailed for fraud, and where has the leap second gone?
item.itunes:subtitle: The investigation will include how Mr Trump handled classified documents
item.itunes:summary: A former war crimes prosecutor, Jack Smith, was named special counsel by US Attorney General, Merrrick Garland. Also: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes jailed for fraud, and where has the leap second gone?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: North Korea launches missile 'capable of reaching US'
item.description: United States condemns launch, while South Korea orders stronger deterrence measures. Also: No alcohol to be sold at World Cup stadiums; and protestors in Iran set fire to ancestral home of Islamic Republic founder, Ayatollah Khomeini.
item.itunes:subtitle: United States condemns launch, while South Korea orders stronger deterrence measures
item.itunes:summary: United States condemns launch, while South Korea orders stronger deterrence measures. Also: No alcohol to be sold at World Cup stadiums; and protestors in Iran set fire to ancestral home of Islamic Republic founder, Ayatollah Khomeini.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: MH17: Three men found guilty of murder
item.description: A Dutch trial finds a missile supplied by Russia killed 298 people over Ukraine in 2014. Also: Spain's new sex abuse law sparks a row over jail terms, and the Hollywood star, Charlize Theron is condemned for saying her native Afrikaans is a dying language.
item.itunes:subtitle: A Dutch trial finds a missile supplied by Russia killed 298 people over Ukraine in 2014
item.itunes:summary: A Dutch trial finds a missile supplied by Russia killed 298 people over Ukraine in 2014. Also: Spain's new sex abuse law sparks a row over jail terms, and the Hollywood star, Charlize Theron is condemned for saying her native Afrikaans is a dying language.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian gas plant hit in latest Russian strikes
item.description: More people are experiencing power cuts, as first snow falls on Kyiv. Also: Iran's rulers crack down on protests in one of the worst nights of violence yet; and months after being scrapped - one of Australia's most successful TV exports gets a reboot.
item.itunes:subtitle: More people are experiencing power cuts, as first snow falls on Kyiv
item.itunes:summary: More people are experiencing power cuts, as first snow falls on Kyiv. Also: Iran's rulers crack down on protests in one of the worst nights of violence yet; and months after being scrapped - one of Australia's most successful TV exports gets a reboot.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Brazil's Lula wows COP 27
item.description: The President elect gets a standing ovation as he promises to fight Amazon deforestation. Also: the US ambassador to the UN accuses President Putin of wanting to freeze Ukraine into submission, and Mariah Carey loses her bid to become the only Queen of Christmas in a trademark court case.
item.itunes:subtitle: The President elect gets a standing ovation as he vows to fight Amazon deforestation
item.itunes:summary: The President elect gets a standing ovation as he promises to fight Amazon deforestation. Also: the US ambassador to the UN accuses President Putin of wanting to freeze Ukraine into submission, and Mariah Carey loses her bid to become the only Queen of Christmas in a trademark court case.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Poland: no sign Tuesday's missile strike was deliberate Russian attack
item.description: NATO and Poland say missile strike was 'likely' caused by Ukraine's air defence. Also: two years after losing the US presidential election, Donald Trump confirms plans to run for the White House in 2024; and Bruce Springsteen fans can rest easy - the Boss himself has settled a dispute about the opening of one of his best loved songs.
item.itunes:subtitle: NATO and Poland say missile strike was 'likely' caused by Ukraine's air defence
item.itunes:summary: NATO and Poland say missile strike was 'likely' caused by Ukraine's air defence. Also: two years after losing the US presidential election, Donald Trump confirms plans to run for the White House in 2024; and Bruce Springsteen fans can rest easy - the Boss himself has settled a dispute about the opening of one of his best loved songs.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia denies stray missile landed in Poland
item.description: Warsaw raises military readiness after explosion near Ukraine border; the US and other international powers say they're investigating. Also: Ukraine says a wave of Russian missile strikes on Tuesday was the biggest against the country's energy system since the invasion in February, and why are sexually transmitted diseases rising among Britain's elderly?
item.itunes:subtitle: Warsaw raises military readiness after explosion near Ukraine border
item.itunes:summary: Warsaw raises military readiness after explosion near Ukraine border; the US and other international powers say they're investigating. Also: Ukraine says a wave of Russian missile strikes on Tuesday was the biggest against the country's energy system since the invasion in February, and why are sexually transmitted diseases rising among Britain's elderly?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Prisoners abused by both sides in Ukraine war
item.description: A UN report details horrific behaviour by both sides. It includes allegations of the torture and summary execution of Russians held by Ukraine -- and beatings, mock executions and the threat of sexual violence suffered by Ukrainian POWs. Also in this edition: the world's population tops eight billion; fresh allegations of migrant World Cup workers killed and injured in Qatar; and how -- just like humans -- chimpanzees like to show and tell.
item.itunes:subtitle: UN report details horrific behaviour
item.itunes:summary: A UN report details horrific behaviour by both sides. It includes allegations of the torture and summary execution of Russians held by Ukraine -- and beatings, mock executions and the threat of sexual violence suffered by Ukrainian POWs. Also in this edition: the world's population tops eight billion; fresh allegations of migrant World Cup workers killed and injured in Qatar; and how -- just like humans -- chimpanzees like to show and tell.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Biden says 'no new cold war' with China
item.description: During lengthy talks the two men also stressed their opposition to the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine. Also: The world's population jumps to 8 billion, doubling since 1974, and Joyland - the Oscar-nominated film causing controversy in Pakistan.
item.itunes:subtitle: The two men also stressed their opposition to the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: During lengthy talks the two men also stressed their opposition to the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine. Also: The world's population jumps to 8 billion, doubling since 1974, and Joyland - the Oscar-nominated film causing controversy in Pakistan.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Presidents Xi and Biden meet
item.description: The three-hour meeting took place in Bali ahead of the annual G20 summit. Also, Britain and France sign a deal to stop migrants making dangerous Channel crossing, and Jeff Bezos plans to give away his fortune.
item.itunes:subtitle: The three-hour meeting took place in Bali ahead of the annual G20 summit
item.itunes:summary: The three-hour meeting took place in Bali ahead of the annual G20 summit. Also, Britain and France sign a deal to stop migrants making dangerous Channel crossing, and Jeff Bezos plans to give away his fortune.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Deadly explosion in Istanbul shopping street
item.description: The Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan described the blast in Istiklal street as a "vile attack". Also: Ukraine says over four hundred Russian "war crimes" reported in Kherson, and thousands of budding writers in the US take part in the National Novel Writing Month
item.itunes:subtitle: Officials believe a woman carried out the attack
item.itunes:summary: The Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan described the blast in Istiklal street as a "vile attack". Also: Ukraine says over four hundred Russian "war crimes" reported in Kherson, and thousands of budding writers in the US take part in the National Novel Writing Month
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Zelensky says Russia destroyed all critical infrastructure in Kherson
item.description: Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelensky said Russian forces had left the city of Kherson with no heat, electricity, water supply or communications. Also: Ethiopia and Tigrayan rebels agree to facilitate aid deliveries into conflict zone, and an Iranian man who lived in a French airport for eighteen years has died.
item.itunes:subtitle: It is feared some Russian troops may have remained behind in disguise
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelensky said Russian forces had left the city of Kherson with no heat, electricity, water supply or communications. Also: Ethiopia and Tigrayan rebels agree to facilitate aid deliveries into conflict zone, and an Iranian man who lived in a French airport for eighteen years has died.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainians celebrate recapture of key city Kherson
item.description: Ukraine says its troops are 'almost fully in control' in Kherson after Russia's retreat. Also: crypto firm FTX collapses into bankruptcy, and could obstacle racing replace show jumping in the modern pentathlon?
item.itunes:subtitle: Kherson is biggest Russian loss since Kyiv setback
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine says its troops are 'almost fully in control' in Kherson after Russia's retreat. Also: crypto firm FTX collapses into bankruptcy, and could obstacle racing replace show jumping in the modern pentathlon?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukrainian flags fly in Kherson after Russian retreat
item.description: Ukraine hails an 'important victory' after Russian troops withdrew from Kherson and Ukrainian flags appear in the city centre. Also: China eases covid controls despite rising cases, and the search for life on Mars takes a new turn.
item.itunes:subtitle: Russia claims full withdrawal of its troops as Ukrainian forces enter the city of Kherson
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine hails an 'important victory' after Russian troops withdrew from Kherson and Ukrainian flags appear in the city centre. Also: China eases covid controls despite rising cases, and the search for life on Mars takes a new turn.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Ukraine claims gains as Russia starts to exit Kherson
item.description: Kyiv reports rapid advances after Moscow said it would leave the key city of Kherson. Also: crypto market rocked by feared collapse of FTX exchange, and do octopuses throw debris in anger?
item.itunes:subtitle: Kherson was the only regional capital to fall into Russian hands
item.itunes:summary: Kyiv reports rapid advances after Moscow said it would leave the key city of Kherson. Also: crypto market rocked by feared collapse of FTX exchange, and do octopuses throw debris in anger?
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia's retreat from Kherson is under way
item.description: Ukraine says Russia had to flee after its forces destroyed Russian supply lines. Also: the Taliban in Afghanistan have banned women from all parks in the capital, Kabul, and how the world's largest lottery win made one lucky shop worker a millionaire.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ukraine says Russia had to flee after its forces destroyed Russian supply lines
item.itunes:summary: Ukraine says Russia had to flee after its forces destroyed Russian supply lines. Also: the Taliban in Afghanistan have banned women from all parks in the capital, Kabul, and how the world's largest lottery win made one lucky shop worker a millionaire.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Russia to withdraw from key Ukrainian city
item.description: Kherson is the only provincial capital Russia has managed to capture since the start of its invasion. Also: President Joe Biden has described Tuesday's mid-term elections as a good day for democracy, and the Brazilian singer, Gal Costa -- the voice of the Tropicalia movement -- has died at the age of 77.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kherson is the only provincial capital Russia has captured since the invasion began
item.itunes:summary: Kherson is the only provincial capital Russia has managed to capture since the start of its invasion. Also: President Joe Biden has described Tuesday's mid-term elections as a good day for democracy, and the Brazilian singer, Gal Costa -- the voice of the Tropicalia movement -- has died at the age of 77.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special episode: Indigenous peoples
item.description: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoplesâ€™ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.
item.itunes:subtitle: We hear from Indigenous listeners around the world as we mark US Indigenous Peoplesâ€™ Day
item.itunes:summary: We hear from our Indigenous and tribal listeners around the world, as we mark US Indigenous Peoplesâ€™ Day. We also meet an Amazon tribe defending their land from illegal loggers; a Maori singer who makes pop music in his traditional language; Native American chefs bringing cultural foods to the restaurant scene; and more.

item.title: Live special episode: Cost of living
item.description: The global price crisis. Our first ever â€œlive audience showâ€ â€“ recorded in Malaysia. Listeners around the world and in the audience in Kuala Lumpur share their experiences and ask questions about spiralling costs and what can be done. Hear from our panel of BBC correspondents. What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?
item.itunes:subtitle: The global price crisis. Our first ever â€live audience showâ€ â€“ recorded in Malaysia

What are the implications of the increases in food and fuel prices? How are governments and communities responding - and what does the future look like?

item.title: Special episode: Abortion rights around the world
item.description:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.
item.itunes:subtitle: We investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally
item.itunes:summary:
In June, the US Supreme Court overruled Roe v Wade and ended the constitutional right to abortion in America. In a special episode, we investigate the changing dynamic of abortion rights globally in countries like Colombia, China and Ireland. We'll also be examining the restrictions still faced by women in Africa and places like Malta and El Salvador.
Audio for this episode was updated on 4 July 2022, due to a factual error in an earlier version.

item.title: Young voices special
item.description:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:subtitle: We took questions on Ukraine from young people around the world
item.itunes:summary:
Is the nuclear threat real? What does Putin want? Who is winning the war in Ukraine? We took questions on the invasion from young people around the world and looked for answers from BBC correspondents.
Jackie Leonard speaks to Martin Forster, a senior child psychologist with the healthcare company, Kry, in Sweden. Listeners' questions are tackled by Vitaliy Shevchenko, Paul Adams, Theo Leggett, Lyse Doucet and Mark Lowen.
item.itunes:author: BBC World Service

item.title: Special: Global News Ukrainecast part 2
item.description:
A month since the Russian invasion of Ukraine, we are collaborating with Ukrainecast again. We answer more of your questions.
Jackie Leonard, presenter of the Global News Podcast, alongside Gabriel Gatehouse and Vitaliy Shevchenko from Ukrainecast, guide us through questions about civilian life in the country, military tactics, and the international response to the invasion.
BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.
This episode was made by Chris Flynn. The studio director was Ash Taylor. The assistant editor was Sam Bonham.
item.itunes:subtitle: We answer more of your questions about Ukraine
item.itunes:summary:

BBC chief international correspondent, Lyse Doucet, joins us from Kyiv to talk through what is happening on the ground there, and BBC security correspondent Frank Gardner, tells us the latest on the physical and information war.

item.title: Omicron versus the world: Your questions answered
item.description: As the Omicron variant spreads around the world and cases surge, BBC correspondents tell us how Covid-19 is impacting our lives, our businesses and our economies.
item.itunes:subtitle: The facts, the science, the politics, the economics and the myths

item.title: Afghanistan Special: Your Questions Answered
item.description:
BBC correspondents answer your questions about the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan. We ask how did the Taliban overthrow the Afghan government so quickly? What now for human rights, the economy and international relations?
Photo:People on board an evacuation flight out of Kabul airport, August 21, 2021 Credit:MoD/PA Wire

item.description: We team up with the award-winning Brexitcast team to bring you a special update on what Britain leaving the EU means for you.
